qa.question: At which point did Billing’s emotional state become irreversibly altered following the revelation of the Baths being unsafe?
option: A. Immediately upon hearing the claim for the first time.
B. After expressing 'Absolutely incredible!' but before any further dialogue.
C. After his statement 'Upon my soul, Doctor, you are going to be the foremost man in the town!'
D. When he realized the implications of the revelation.
E. There is no irreversible alteration in his emotional state.
qa.answer: C. After his statement 'Upon my soul, Doctor, you are going to be the foremost man in the town!'
qa.reasoning: Billing’s initial reaction to the revelation was shock ('Absolutely incredible!'), but this was not yet an irreversible change in emotional state. Only after he expressed admiration for Dr. Stockmann ('Upon my soul, Doctor, you are going to be the foremost man in the town!') did his emotional state become clearly aligned with admiration rather than disbelief or dismissal. This moment marks the point at which his state became final and irreversible, as it reflects a full shift in perspective. Earlier moments could still have been interpreted as disbelief or confusion, but this statement confirms the transition.

session_1.speaker: NARRATION
session_1.text: (SCENE.—DR. STOCKMANN'S sitting-room. It is evening. The room is plainly but neatly appointed and furnished. In the right-hand wall are two doors; the farther leads out to the hall, the nearer to the doctor's study. In the left-hand wall, opposite the door leading to the hall, is a door leading to the other rooms occupied by the family. In the middle of the same wall stands the stove, and, further forward, a couch with a looking-glass hanging over it and an oval table in front of it. On the table, a lighted lamp, with a lampshade. At the back of the room, an open door leads to the dining-room. BILLING is seen sitting at the dining table, on which a lamp is burning. He has a napkin tucked under his chin, and MRS. STOCKMANN is standing by the table handing him a large plate-full of roast beef. The other places at the table are empty, and the table somewhat in disorder, evidently a meal having recently been finished.)

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: You see, if you come an hour late, Mr. Billing, you have to put up with cold meat.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: It is uncommonly good, thank you—remarkably good.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: My husband makes such a point of having his meals punctually, you know.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: That doesn't affect me a bit. Indeed, I almost think I enjoy a meal all the better when I can sit down and eat all by myself, and undisturbed.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh well, as long as you are enjoying it—. I expect that is Mr. Hovstad coming too.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Very likely.

session_1.speaker: STAGE
session_1.text: (PETER STOCKMANN comes in. He wears an overcoat and his official hat, and carries a stick.)

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Good evening, Katherine.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Ah, good evening—is it you? How good of you to come up and see us!

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: I happened to be passing, and so—. But you have company with you, I see.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, no—it was quite by chance he came in. Won't you come in and have something, too?

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: I! No, thank you. Good gracious—hot meat at night! Not with my digestion.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, but just once in a way—

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: No, no, my dear lady; I stick to my tea and bread and butter. It is much more wholesome in the long run—and a little more economical, too.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Now you mustn't think that Thomas and I are spendthrifts.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Not you, my dear; I would never think that of you. Is he not at home?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: No, he went out for a little turn after supper—he and the boys.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: I doubt if that is a wise thing to do. I fancy I hear him coming now.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: No, I don't think it is he. Come in! Oh, it is you, Mr. Hovstad!

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Yes, I hope you will forgive me, but I was delayed at the printers. Good evening, Mr. Mayor.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Good evening. You have come on business, no doubt.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Partly. It's about an article for the paper.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: So I imagined. I hear my brother has become a prolific contributor to the "People's Messenger."

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Yes, he is good enough to write in the "People's Messenger" when he has any home truths to tell.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: But won't you—? (Points to the dining-room.)

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Quite so, quite so. I don't blame him in the least, as a writer, for addressing himself to the quarters where he will find the readiest sympathy. And, besides that, I personally have no reason to bear any ill will to your paper, Mr. Hovstad.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: I quite agree with you.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Taking one thing with another, there is an excellent spirit of toleration in the town—an admirable municipal spirit. And it all springs from the fact of our having a great common interest to unite us—an interest that is in an equally high degree the concern of every right-minded citizen.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: The Baths, yes.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Exactly—-our fine, new, handsome Baths. Mark my words, Mr. Hovstad—the Baths will become the focus of our municipal life! Not a doubt of it!

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: That is just what Thomas says.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Think how extraordinarily the place has developed within the last year or two! Money has been flowing in, and there is some life and some business doing in the town. Houses and landed property are rising in value every day.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: And unemployment is diminishing,

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, that is another thing. The burden on the poor rates has been lightened, to the great relief of the propertied classes; and that relief will be even greater if only we get a really good summer this year, and lots of visitors—plenty of invalids, who will make the Baths talked about.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: And there is a good prospect of that, I hear.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: It looks very promising. Inquiries about apartments and that sort of thing are reaching us, every day.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Well, the doctor's article will come in very suitably.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Has he been writing something just lately?

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: This is something he wrote in the winter; a recommendation of the Baths—an account of the excellent sanitary conditions here. But I held the article over, temporarily.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Ah,—some little difficulty about it, I suppose?

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: No, not at all; I thought it would be better to wait until the spring, because it is just at this time that people begin to think seriously about their summer quarters.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Quite right; you were perfectly right, Mr. Hovstad.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Yes, Thomas is really indefatigable when it is a question of the Baths.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Well remember, he is the Medical Officer to the Baths.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Yes, and what is more, they owe their existence to him.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: To him? Indeed! It is true I have heard from time to time that some people are of that opinion. At the same time I must say I imagined that I took a modest part in the enterprise.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, that is what Thomas is always saying.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: But who denies it, Mr. Stockmann? You set the thing going and made a practical concern of it; we all know that. I only meant that the idea of it came first from the doctor.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, ideas yes! My brother has had plenty of them in his time—unfortunately. But when it is a question of putting an idea into practical shape, you have to apply to a man of different mettle, Mr. Hovstad. And I certainly should have thought that in this house at least...

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: My dear Peter—

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: How can you think that—?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Won't you go in and have something, Mr. Hovstad? My husband is sure to be back directly.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Thank you, perhaps just a morsel.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: It is a curious thing that these farmers' sons never seem to lose their want of tact.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Surely it is not worth bothering about! Cannot you and Thomas share the credit as brothers?

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: I should have thought so; but apparently some people are not satisfied with a share.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: What nonsense! You and Thomas get on so capitally together.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Look here—here is another guest for you, Katherine. Isn't that jolly! Come in, Captain Horster; hang your coat up on this peg. Ah, you don't wear an overcoat. Just think, Katherine; I met him in the street and could hardly persuade him to come up! Come along in, boys. They are ravenously hungry again, you know. Come along, Captain Horster; you must have a slice of beef.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: But, Thomas, don't you see—?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, is it you, Peter? Now that is very delightful.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Unfortunately I must go in a moment—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Rubbish! There is some toddy just coming in. You haven't forgotten the toddy, Katherine?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Of course not; the water is boiling now.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Toddy too!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, sit down and we will have it comfortably.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Thanks, I never care about an evening's drinking.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: But this isn't an evening's drinking.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: It seems to me—. It is extraordinary how they can put away all that food.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, isn't it splendid to see young people eat? They have always got an appetite, you know! That's as it should be. Lots of food—to build up their strength! They are the people who are going to stir up the fermenting forces of the future, Peter.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: May I ask what they will find here to "stir up," as you put it?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Ah, you must ask the young people that—when the times comes. We shan't be able to see it, of course. That stands to reason—two old fogies, like us.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Really, really! I must say that is an extremely odd expression to—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, you mustn't take me too literally, Peter. I am so heartily happy and contented, you know. I think it is such an extraordinary piece of good fortune to be in the middle of all this growing, germinating life. It is a splendid time to live in! It is as if a whole new world were being created around one.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Do you really think so?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Ah, naturally you can't appreciate it as keenly as I. You have lived all your life in these surroundings, and your impressions have been blunted. But I, who have been buried all these years in my little corner up north, almost without ever seeing a stranger who might bring new ideas with him—well, in my case it has just the same effect as if I had been transported into the middle of a crowded city.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, a city—!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: I know, I know; it is all cramped enough here, compared with many other places. But there is life here—there is promise—there are innumerable things to work for and fight for; and that is the main thing. Calls. Katherine, hasn't the postman been here?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: No.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: And then to be comfortably off, Peter! That is something one learns to value, when one has been on the brink of starvation, as we have.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, surely—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Indeed I can assure you we have often been very hard put to it, up there. And now to be able to live like a lord! Today, for instance, we had roast beef for dinner—and, what is more, for supper too. Won't you come and have a little bit? Or let me show it you, at any rate? Come here—

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: No, no—not for worlds!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Well, but just come here then. Do you see, we have got a table-cover?

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, I noticed it.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: And we have got a lamp-shade too. Do you see? All out of Katherine's savings! It makes the room so cosy. Don't you think so? Just stand here for a moment—no, no, not there—just here, that's it! Look now, when you get the light on it altogether. I really think it looks very nice, doesn't it?

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, if you can afford luxuries of this kind—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, I can afford it now. Katherine tells me I earn almost as much as we spend.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Almost—yes!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: But a scientific man must live in a little bit of style. I am quite sure an ordinary civil servant spends more in a year than I do.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: I daresay. A civil servant—a man in a well-paid position...

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Well, any ordinary merchant, then! A man in that position spends two or three times as much as—

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: It just depends on circumstances.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: At all events I assure you I don't waste money unprofitably. But I can't find it in my heart to deny myself the pleasure of entertaining my friends. I need that sort of thing, you know. I have lived for so long shut out of it all, that it is a necessity of life to me to mix with young, eager, ambitious men, men of liberal and active minds; and that describes every one of those fellows who are enjoying their supper in there. I wish you knew more of Hovstad.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: By the way, Hovstad was telling me he was going to print another article of yours.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: An article of mine?

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, about the Baths. An article you wrote in the winter.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, that one! No, I don't intend that to appear just for the present.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Why not? It seems to me that this would be the most opportune moment.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, very likely—under normal conditions.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Is there anything abnormal about the present conditions?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: To tell you the truth, Peter, I can't say just at this moment—at all events not tonight. There may be much that is very abnormal about the present conditions—and it is possible there may be nothing abnormal about them at all. It is quite possible it may be merely my imagination.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: I must say it all sounds most mysterious. Is there something going on that I am to be kept in ignorance of? I should have imagined that I, as Chairman of the governing body of the Baths—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: And I should have imagined that I—. Oh, come, don't let us fly out at one another, Peter.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: Heaven forbid! I am not in the habit of flying out at people, as you call it. But I am entitled to request most emphatically that all arrangements shall be made in a businesslike manner, through the proper channels, and shall be dealt with by the legally constituted authorities. I can allow no going behind our backs by any roundabout means.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Have I ever at any time tried to go behind your backs?

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: You have an ingrained tendency to take your own way, at all events; and, that is almost equally inadmissible in a well ordered community. The individual ought undoubtedly to acquiesce in subordinating himself to the community—or, to speak more accurately, to the authorities who have the care of the community's welfare.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Very likely. But what the deuce has all this got to do with me?

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: That is exactly what you never appear to be willing to learn, my dear Thomas. But, mark my words, some day you will have to suffer for it—sooner or later. Now I have told you. Good-bye.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Have you taken leave of your senses? You are on the wrong scent altogether.

session_1.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_1.text: I am not usually that. You must excuse me now if I—

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Has he gone?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, and in such a bad temper.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: But, dear Thomas, what have you been doing to him again?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Nothing at all. And, anyhow, he can't oblige me to make my report before the proper time.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: What have you got to make a report to him about?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Hm! Leave that to me, Katherine. It is an extraordinary thing that the postman doesn't come.

session_1.speaker: STAGE
session_1.text: (HOVSTAD, BILLING and HORSTER have got up from the table and come into the sitting-room. EJLIF and MORTEN come in after them.)

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Ah!—one feels a new man after a meal like that.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: The mayor wasn't in a very sweet temper tonight, then.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: It is his stomach; he has wretched digestion.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: I rather think it was us two of the "People's Messenger" that couldn't digest.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: I thought you came out of it pretty well with him.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Oh yes; but it isn't anything more than a sort of truce.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: That is just what it is! That word sums up the situation.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: We must remember that Peter is a lonely man, poor chap. He has no home comforts of any kind; nothing but everlasting business. And all that infernal weak tea wash that he pours into himself! Now then, my boys, bring chairs up to the table. Aren't we going to have that toddy, Katherine?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: I am just getting it.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Sit down here on the couch beside me, Captain Horster. We so seldom see you. Please sit down, my friends.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: There you are! This is arrack, and this is rum, and this one is the brandy. Now every one must help themselves.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: We will. And let us have the cigars. Ejlif, you know where the box is. And you, Morten, can fetch my pipe. I have a suspicion that Ejlif pockets a cigar now and then!—but I take no notice of it. And my smoking-cap too, Morten. Katherine, you can tell him where I left it. Ah, he has got it. Now, my friends. I stick to my pipe, you know. This one has seen plenty of bad weather with me up north. Touches glasses with them. Your good health! Ah, it is good to be sitting snug and warm here.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Do you sail soon, Captain Horster?

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: I expect to be ready to sail next week.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: I suppose you are going to America?

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: Yes, that is the plan.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Then you won't be able to take part in the coming election?

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: Is there going to be an election?

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Didn't you know?

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: No, I don't mix myself up with those things.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: But do you not take an interest in public affairs?

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: No, I don't know anything about politics.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: All the same, one ought to vote, at any rate.

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: Even if one doesn't know anything about what is going on?

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Doesn't know! What do you mean by that? A community is like a ship; everyone ought to be prepared to take the helm.

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: Maybe that is all very well on shore; but on board ship it wouldn't work.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: It is astonishing how little most sailors care about what goes on on shore.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Very extraordinary.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Sailors are like birds of passage; they feel equally at home in any latitude. And that is only an additional reason for our being all the more keen, Hovstad. Is there to be anything of public interest in tomorrow's "Messenger"?

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Nothing about municipal affairs. But the day after tomorrow I was thinking of printing your article—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Ah, devil take it—my article! Look here, that must wait a bit.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Really? We had just got convenient space for it, and I thought it was just the opportune moment—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, yes, very likely you are right; but it must wait all the same. I will explain to you later.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Good evening.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Good evening, Petra; come along.

session_1.speaker: STAGE
session_1.text: (Mutual greetings; PETRA takes off her things and puts them down on a chair by the door.)

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: And you have all been sitting here enjoying yourselves, while I have been out slaving!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Well, come and enjoy yourself too!

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: May I mix a glass for you?

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Thanks, I would rather do it; you always mix it too strong. But I forgot, father—I have a letter for you.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: A letter? From whom?

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: The postman gave it to me just as I was going out.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: And you only give to me now!

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: I really had not time to run up again. There it is!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Let's see, let's see, child! (Looks at the address.) Yes, that's all right!

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Is it the one you have been expecting go anxiously, Thomas?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, it is. I must go to my room now and— Where shall I get a light, Katherine? Is there no lamp in my room again?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, your lamp is already lit on your desk.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Good, good. Excuse me for a moment—

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: What do you suppose it is, mother?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: I don't know; for the last day or two he has always been asking if the postman has not been.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Probably some country patient.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Poor old dad!—he will overwork himself soon. There, that will taste good!

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Have you been teaching in the evening school again today?

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Two hours.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: And four hours of school in the morning?

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Five hours.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: And you have still got exercises to correct, I see.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: A whole heap, yes.

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: You are pretty full up with work too, it seems to me.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Yes—but that is good. One is so delightfully tired after it.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Do you like that?

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Yes, because one sleeps so well then.

session_1.speaker: Morten
session_1.text: You must be dreadfully wicked, Petra.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Wicked?

session_1.speaker: Morten
session_1.text: Yes, because you work so much. Mr. Rorlund says work is a punishment for our sins.

session_1.speaker: Ejlif
session_1.text: Pooh, what a duffer, you are, to believe a thing like that!

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Come, come, Ejlif!

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: That's capital!

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Don't you want to work as hard as that, Morten?

session_1.speaker: Morten
session_1.text: No, indeed I don't.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: What do you want to be, then?

session_1.speaker: Morten
session_1.text: I should like best to be a Viking,

session_1.speaker: Ejlif
session_1.text: You would have to be a pagan then.

session_1.speaker: Morten
session_1.text: Well, I could become a pagan, couldn't I?

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: I agree with you, Morten! My sentiments, exactly.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: I am sure that is not true, Mr. Billing.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Yes, I swear it is! I am a pagan, and I am proud of it. Believe me, before long we shall all be pagans.

session_1.speaker: Morten
session_1.text: And then shall be allowed to do anything we like?

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Well, you'll see, Morten.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: You must go to your room now, boys; I am sure you have some lessons to learn for tomorrow.

session_1.speaker: Ejlif
session_1.text: I should like so much to stay a little longer—

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: No, no; away you go, both of you,

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Do you really think it can do the boys any harm to hear such things?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: I don't know; but I don't like it.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: But you know, mother, I think you really are wrong about it.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Maybe, but I don't like it—not in our own home.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: There is so much falsehood both at home and at school. At home one must not speak, and at school we have to stand and tell lies to the children.

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: Tell lies?

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Yes, don't you suppose we have to teach them all sorts of things that we don't believe?

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: That is perfectly true.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: If only I had the means, I would start a school of my own; and it would be conducted on very different lines.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Oh, bother the means—!

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: Well if you are thinking of that, Miss Stockmann, I shall be delighted to provide you with a schoolroom. The great big old house my father left me is standing almost empty; there is an immense dining-room downstairs—

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Thank you very much; but I am afraid nothing will come of it.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: No, Miss Petra is much more likely to take to journalism, I expect. By the way, have you had time to do anything with that English story you promised to translate for us?

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: No, not yet, but you shall have it in good time.

session_1.speaker: STAGE
session_1.text: (DR. STOCKMANN comes in from his room with an open letter in his hand.)

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Well, now the town will have something new to talk about, I can tell you!

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Something new?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: What is this?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: A great discovery, Katherine.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Really?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: A discovery of yours?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: A discovery of mine. Just let them come saying, as usual, that it is all fancy and a crazy man's imagination! But they will be careful what they say this time, I can tell you!

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: But, father, tell us what it is.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, yes—only give me time, and you shall know all about it. If only I had Peter here now! It just shows how we men can go about forming our judgments, when in reality we are as blind as any moles—

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: What are you driving at, Doctor?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Isn't it the universal opinion that our town is a healthy spot?

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Certainly.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Quite an unusually healthy spot, in fact—a place that deserves to be recommended in the warmest possible manner either for invalids or for people who are well—

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, but my dear Thomas—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: And we have been recommending it and praising it—I have written and written, both in the "Messenger" and in pamphlets...

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Well, what then?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: And the Baths—we have called them the "main artery of the town's life-blood," the "nerve-centre of our town," and the devil knows what else—

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: "The town's pulsating heart" was the expression I once used on an important occasion.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Quite so. Well, do you know what they really are, these great, splendid, much praised Baths, that have cost so much money—do you know what they are?

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: No, what are they?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, what are they?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: The whole place is a pest-house!

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: The Baths, father?

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Our Baths?

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: But, Doctor—

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Absolutely incredible!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: The whole Bath establishment is a whited, poisoned sepulchre, I tell you—the gravest possible danger to the public health! All the nastiness up at Molledal, all that stinking filth, is infecting the water in the conduit-pipes leading to the reservoir; and the same cursed, filthy poison oozes out on the shore too—

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: Where the bathing-place is?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Just there.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: How do you come to be so certain of all this, Doctor?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: I have investigated the matter most conscientiously. For a long time past I have suspected something of the kind. Last year we had some very strange cases of illness among the visitors—typhoid cases, and cases of gastric fever—

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, that is quite true.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: At the time, we supposed the visitors had been infected before they came; but later on, in the winter, I began to have a different opinion; and so I set myself to examine the water, as well as I could.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Then that is what you have been so busy with?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Indeed I have been busy, Katherine. But here I had none of the necessary scientific apparatus; so I sent samples, both of the drinking-water and of the sea-water, up to the University, to have an accurate analysis made by a chemist.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: And have you got that?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Here it is! It proves the presence of decomposing organic matter in the water—it is full of infusoria. The water is absolutely dangerous to use, either internally or externally.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: What a mercy you discovered it in time.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: You may well say so.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: And what do you propose to do now, Doctor?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: To see the matter put right, naturally.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Can that be done?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: It must be done. Otherwise the Baths will be absolutely useless and wasted. But we need not anticipate that; I have a very clear idea what we shall have to do.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: But why have you kept this all so secret, dear?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Do you suppose I was going to run about the town gossiping about it, before I had absolute proof? No, thank you. I am not such a fool.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Still, you might have told us—

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Not a living soul. But tomorrow you may run around to the old Badger—

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: Oh, Thomas! Thomas!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Well, to your grandfather, then. The old boy will have something to be astonished at! I know he thinks I am cracked—and there are lots of other people who think so too, I have noticed. But now these good folks shall see—they shall just see! There will be a nice upset in the town, Katherine; you can't imagine what it will be. All the conduit-pipes will have to be relaid.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: All the conduit-pipes—?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Yes, of course. The intake is too low down; it will have to be lifted to a position much higher up.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Then you were right after all.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Ah, you remember, Petra—I wrote opposing the plans before the work was begun. But at that time no one would listen to me. Well, I am going to let them have it now.  Of course I have prepared a report for the Baths Committee; I have had it ready for a week, and was only waiting for this to come. Now it shall go off at once. Look at that! Four closely written sheets!—and the letter shall go with them. Give me a bit of paper, Katherine—something to wrap them up in. That will do! Now give it to-to-(stamps his foot)—what the deuce is her name?—give it to the maid, and tell her to take it at once to the Mayor.

session_1.speaker: STAGE
session_1.text: (Mrs. Stockmann takes the packet and goes out through the dining-room.)

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: What do you think Uncle Peter will say, father?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: What is there for him to say? I should think he would be very glad that such an important truth has been brought to light.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: Will you let me print a short note about your discovery in the Messenger?

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: I shall be very much obliged if you will.

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: It is very desirable that the public should be informed of it without delay.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Certainly.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: She has just gone with it.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Upon my soul, Doctor, you are going to be the foremost man in the town!

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Nonsense! As a matter offact I have done nothing more than my duty. I have only made a lucky find—that's all. Still, all the same...

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: Hovstad, don't you think the town ought to give Dr. Stockmann some sort of testimonial?

session_1.speaker: Hovstad
session_1.text: I will suggest it, anyway.

session_1.speaker: Billing
session_1.text: And I will speak to Aslaksen about it.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: No, my good friends, don't let us have any of that nonsense. I won't hear anything of the kind. And if the Baths Committee should think of voting me an increase of salary, I will not accept it. Do you hear, Katherine?—I won't accept it.

session_1.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_1.text: You are quite right, Thomas.

session_1.speaker: Petra
session_1.text: Your health, father!

session_1.speaker: Hovstad and Billing
session_1.text: Your health, Doctor! Good health!

session_1.speaker: Horster
session_1.text: I hope it will bring you nothing but good luck.

session_1.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_1.text: Thank you, thank you, my dear fellows! I feel tremendously happy! It is a splendid thing for a man to be able to feel that he has done a service to his native town and to his fellow-citizens. Hurrah, Katherine!

session_2.speaker: NARRATION
session_2.text: (SCENE.—DR. STOCKMANN'S sitting-room. It is evening. The room is plainly but neatly appointed and furnished. In the right-hand wall are two doors; the farther leads out to the hall, the nearer to the doctor's study. In the left-hand wall, opposite the door leading to the hall, is a door leading to the other rooms occupied by the family. In the middle of the same wall stands the stove, and, further forward, a couch with a looking-glass hanging over it and an oval table in front of it. On the table, a lighted lamp, with a lampshade. At the back of the room, an open door leads to the dining-room. BILLING is seen sitting at the dining table, on which a lamp is burning. He has a napkin tucked under his chin, and MRS. STOCKMANN is standing by the table handing him a large plate-full of roast beef. The other places at the table are empty, and the table somewhat in disorder, evidently a meal having recently been finished.)

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: You see, if you come an hour late, Mr. Billing, you have to put up with cold meat.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: It is uncommonly good, thank you—remarkably good.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: My husband makes such a point of having his meals punctually, you know.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: That doesn't affect me a bit. Indeed, I almost think I enjoy a meal all the better when I can sit down and eat all by myself, and undisturbed.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh well, as long as you are enjoying it—. I expect that is Mr. Hovstad coming too.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Very likely.

session_2.speaker: STAGE
session_2.text: (PETER STOCKMANN comes in. He wears an overcoat and his official hat, and carries a stick.)

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Good evening, Katherine.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Ah, good evening—is it you? How good of you to come up and see us!

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: I happened to be passing, and so—. But you have company with you, I see.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, no—it was quite by chance he came in. Won't you come in and have something, too?

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: I! No, thank you. Good gracious—hot meat at night! Not with my digestion.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, but just once in a way—

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: No, no, my dear lady; I stick to my tea and bread and butter. It is much more wholesome in the long run—and a little more economical, too.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Now you mustn't think that Thomas and I are spendthrifts.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Not you, my dear; I would never think that of you. Is he not at home?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: No, he went out for a little turn after supper—he and the boys.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: I doubt if that is a wise thing to do. I fancy I hear him coming now.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: No, I don't think it is he. Come in! Oh, it is you, Mr. Hovstad!

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Yes, I hope you will forgive me, but I was delayed at the printers. Good evening, Mr. Mayor.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Good evening. You have come on business, no doubt.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Partly. It's about an article for the paper.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: So I imagined. I hear my brother has become a prolific contributor to the "People's Messenger."

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Yes, he is good enough to write in the "People's Messenger" when he has any home truths to tell.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: But won't you—? (Points to the dining-room.)

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Quite so, quite so. I don't blame him in the least, as a writer, for addressing himself to the quarters where he will find the readiest sympathy. And, besides that, I personally have no reason to bear any ill will to your paper, Mr. Hovstad.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: I quite agree with you.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Taking one thing with another, there is an excellent spirit of toleration in the town—an admirable municipal spirit. And it all springs from the fact of our having a great common interest to unite us—an interest that is in an equally high degree the concern of every right-minded citizen.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: The Baths, yes.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Exactly—-our fine, new, handsome Baths. Mark my words, Mr. Hovstad—the Baths will become the focus of our municipal life! Not a doubt of it!

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: That is just what Thomas says.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Think how extraordinarily the place has developed within the last year or two! Money has been flowing in, and there is some life and some business doing in the town. Houses and landed property are rising in value every day.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: And unemployment is diminishing,

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, that is another thing. The burden on the poor rates has been lightened, to the great relief of the propertied classes; and that relief will be even greater if only we get a really good summer this year, and lots of visitors—plenty of invalids, who will make the Baths talked about.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: And there is a good prospect of that, I hear.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: It looks very promising. Inquiries about apartments and that sort of thing are reaching us, every day.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Well, the doctor's article will come in very suitably.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Has he been writing something just lately?

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: This is something he wrote in the winter; a recommendation of the Baths—an account of the excellent sanitary conditions here. But I held the article over, temporarily.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Ah,—some little difficulty about it, I suppose?

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: No, not at all; I thought it would be better to wait until the spring, because it is just at this time that people begin to think seriously about their summer quarters.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Quite right; you were perfectly right, Mr. Hovstad.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Yes, Thomas is really indefatigable when it is a question of the Baths.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Well remember, he is the Medical Officer to the Baths.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Yes, and what is more, they owe their existence to him.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: To him? Indeed! It is true I have heard from time to time that some people are of that opinion. At the same time I must say I imagined that I took a modest part in the enterprise.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, that is what Thomas is always saying.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: But who denies it, Mr. Stockmann? You set the thing going and made a practical concern of it; we all know that. I only meant that the idea of it came first from the doctor.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, ideas yes! My brother has had plenty of them in his time—unfortunately. But when it is a question of putting an idea into practical shape, you have to apply to a man of different mettle, Mr. Hovstad. And I certainly should have thought that in this house at least...

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: My dear Peter—

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: How can you think that—?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Won't you go in and have something, Mr. Hovstad? My husband is sure to be back directly.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Thank you, perhaps just a morsel.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: It is a curious thing that these farmers' sons never seem to lose their want of tact.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Surely it is not worth bothering about! Cannot you and Thomas share the credit as brothers?

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: I should have thought so; but apparently some people are not satisfied with a share.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: What nonsense! You and Thomas get on so capitally together.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Look here—here is another guest for you, Katherine. Isn't that jolly! Come in, Captain Horster; hang your coat up on this peg. Ah, you don't wear an overcoat. Just think, Katherine; I met him in the street and could hardly persuade him to come up! Come along in, boys. They are ravenously hungry again, you know. Come along, Captain Horster; you must have a slice of beef.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: But, Thomas, don't you see—?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, is it you, Peter? Now that is very delightful.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Unfortunately I must go in a moment—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Rubbish! There is some toddy just coming in. You haven't forgotten the toddy, Katherine?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Of course not; the water is boiling now.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Toddy too!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, sit down and we will have it comfortably.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Thanks, I never care about an evening's drinking.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: But this isn't an evening's drinking.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: It seems to me—. It is extraordinary how they can put away all that food.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, isn't it splendid to see young people eat? They have always got an appetite, you know! That's as it should be. Lots of food—to build up their strength! They are the people who are going to stir up the fermenting forces of the future, Peter.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: May I ask what they will find here to "stir up," as you put it?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Ah, you must ask the young people that—when the times comes. We shan't be able to see it, of course. That stands to reason—two old fogies, like us.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Really, really! I must say that is an extremely odd expression to—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, you mustn't take me too literally, Peter. I am so heartily happy and contented, you know. I think it is such an extraordinary piece of good fortune to be in the middle of all this growing, germinating life. It is a splendid time to live in! It is as if a whole new world were being created around one.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Do you really think so?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Ah, naturally you can't appreciate it as keenly as I. You have lived all your life in these surroundings, and your impressions have been blunted. But I, who have been buried all these years in my little corner up north, almost without ever seeing a stranger who might bring new ideas with him—well, in my case it has just the same effect as if I had been transported into the middle of a crowded city.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, a city—!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: I know, I know; it is all cramped enough here, compared with many other places. But there is life here—there is promise—there are innumerable things to work for and fight for; and that is the main thing. Calls. Katherine, hasn't the postman been here?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: No.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: And then to be comfortably off, Peter! That is something one learns to value, when one has been on the brink of starvation, as we have.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, surely—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Indeed I can assure you we have often been very hard put to it, up there. And now to be able to live like a lord! Today, for instance, we had roast beef for dinner—and, what is more, for supper too. Won't you come and have a little bit? Or let me show it you, at any rate? Come here—

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: No, no—not for worlds!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Well, but just come here then. Do you see, we have got a table-cover?

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, I noticed it.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: And we have got a lamp-shade too. Do you see? All out of Katherine's savings! It makes the room so cosy. Don't you think so? Just stand here for a moment—no, no, not there—just here, that's it! Look now, when you get the light on it altogether. I really think it looks very nice, doesn't it?

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, if you can afford luxuries of this kind—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, I can afford it now. Katherine tells me I earn almost as much as we spend.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Almost—yes!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: But a scientific man must live in a little bit of style. I am quite sure an ordinary civil servant spends more in a year than I do.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: I daresay. A civil servant—a man in a well-paid position...

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Well, any ordinary merchant, then! A man in that position spends two or three times as much as—

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: It just depends on circumstances.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: At all events I assure you I don't waste money unprofitably. But I can't find it in my heart to deny myself the pleasure of entertaining my friends. I need that sort of thing, you know. I have lived for so long shut out of it all, that it is a necessity of life to me to mix with young, eager, ambitious men, men of liberal and active minds; and that describes every one of those fellows who are enjoying their supper in there. I wish you knew more of Hovstad.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: By the way, Hovstad was telling me he was going to print another article of yours.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: An article of mine?

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, about the Baths. An article you wrote in the winter.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, that one! No, I don't intend that to appear just for the present.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Why not? It seems to me that this would be the most opportune moment.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, very likely—under normal conditions.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Is there anything abnormal about the present conditions?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: To tell you the truth, Peter, I can't say just at this moment—at all events not tonight. There may be much that is very abnormal about the present conditions—and it is possible there may be nothing abnormal about them at all. It is quite possible it may be merely my imagination.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: I must say it all sounds most mysterious. Is there something going on that I am to be kept in ignorance of? I should have imagined that I, as Chairman of the governing body of the Baths—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: And I should have imagined that I—. Oh, come, don't let us fly out at one another, Peter.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: Heaven forbid! I am not in the habit of flying out at people, as you call it. But I am entitled to request most emphatically that all arrangements shall be made in a businesslike manner, through the proper channels, and shall be dealt with by the legally constituted authorities. I can allow no going behind our backs by any roundabout means.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Have I ever at any time tried to go behind your backs?

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: You have an ingrained tendency to take your own way, at all events; and, that is almost equally inadmissible in a well ordered community. The individual ought undoubtedly to acquiesce in subordinating himself to the community—or, to speak more accurately, to the authorities who have the care of the community's welfare.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Very likely. But what the deuce has all this got to do with me?

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: That is exactly what you never appear to be willing to learn, my dear Thomas. But, mark my words, some day you will have to suffer for it—sooner or later. Now I have told you. Good-bye.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Have you taken leave of your senses? You are on the wrong scent altogether.

session_2.speaker: Peter Stockmann
session_2.text: I am not usually that. You must excuse me now if I—

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Has he gone?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, and in such a bad temper.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: But, dear Thomas, what have you been doing to him again?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Nothing at all. And, anyhow, he can't oblige me to make my report before the proper time.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: What have you got to make a report to him about?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Hm! Leave that to me, Katherine. It is an extraordinary thing that the postman doesn't come.

session_2.speaker: STAGE
session_2.text: (HOVSTAD, BILLING and HORSTER have got up from the table and come into the sitting-room. EJLIF and MORTEN come in after them.)

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Ah!—one feels a new man after a meal like that.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: The mayor wasn't in a very sweet temper tonight, then.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: It is his stomach; he has wretched digestion.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: I rather think it was us two of the "People's Messenger" that couldn't digest.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: I thought you came out of it pretty well with him.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Oh yes; but it isn't anything more than a sort of truce.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: That is just what it is! That word sums up the situation.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: We must remember that Peter is a lonely man, poor chap. He has no home comforts of any kind; nothing but everlasting business. And all that infernal weak tea wash that he pours into himself! Now then, my boys, bring chairs up to the table. Aren't we going to have that toddy, Katherine?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: I am just getting it.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Sit down here on the couch beside me, Captain Horster. We so seldom see you. Please sit down, my friends.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: There you are! This is arrack, and this is rum, and this one is the brandy. Now every one must help themselves.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: We will. And let us have the cigars. Ejlif, you know where the box is. And you, Morten, can fetch my pipe. I have a suspicion that Ejlif pockets a cigar now and then!—but I take no notice of it. And my smoking-cap too, Morten. Katherine, you can tell him where I left it. Ah, he has got it. Now, my friends. I stick to my pipe, you know. This one has seen plenty of bad weather with me up north. Touches glasses with them. Your good health! Ah, it is good to be sitting snug and warm here.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Do you sail soon, Captain Horster?

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: I expect to be ready to sail next week.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: I suppose you are going to America?

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: Yes, that is the plan.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Then you won't be able to take part in the coming election?

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: Is there going to be an election?

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Didn't you know?

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: No, I don't mix myself up with those things.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: But do you not take an interest in public affairs?

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: No, I don't know anything about politics.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: All the same, one ought to vote, at any rate.

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: Even if one doesn't know anything about what is going on?

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Doesn't know! What do you mean by that? A community is like a ship; everyone ought to be prepared to take the helm.

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: Maybe that is all very well on shore; but on board ship it wouldn't work.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: It is astonishing how little most sailors care about what goes on on shore.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Very extraordinary.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Sailors are like birds of passage; they feel equally at home in any latitude. And that is only an additional reason for our being all the more keen, Hovstad. Is there to be anything of public interest in tomorrow's "Messenger"?

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Nothing about municipal affairs. But the day after tomorrow I was thinking of printing your article—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Ah, devil take it—my article! Look here, that must wait a bit.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Really? We had just got convenient space for it, and I thought it was just the opportune moment—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, yes, very likely you are right; but it must wait all the same. I will explain to you later.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Good evening.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Good evening, Petra; come along.

session_2.speaker: STAGE
session_2.text: (Mutual greetings; PETRA takes off her things and puts them down on a chair by the door.)

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: And you have all been sitting here enjoying yourselves, while I have been out slaving!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Well, come and enjoy yourself too!

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: May I mix a glass for you?

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Thanks, I would rather do it; you always mix it too strong. But I forgot, father—I have a letter for you.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: A letter? From whom?

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: The postman gave it to me just as I was going out.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: And you only give to me now!

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: I really had not time to run up again. There it is!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Let's see, let's see, child! (Looks at the address.) Yes, that's all right!

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Is it the one you have been expecting go anxiously, Thomas?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, it is. I must go to my room now and— Where shall I get a light, Katherine? Is there no lamp in my room again?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, your lamp is already lit on your desk.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Good, good. Excuse me for a moment—

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: What do you suppose it is, mother?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: I don't know; for the last day or two he has always been asking if the postman has not been.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Probably some country patient.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Poor old dad!—he will overwork himself soon. There, that will taste good!

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Have you been teaching in the evening school again today?

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Two hours.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: And four hours of school in the morning?

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Five hours.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: And you have still got exercises to correct, I see.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: A whole heap, yes.

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: You are pretty full up with work too, it seems to me.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Yes—but that is good. One is so delightfully tired after it.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Do you like that?

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Yes, because one sleeps so well then.

session_2.speaker: Morten
session_2.text: You must be dreadfully wicked, Petra.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Wicked?

session_2.speaker: Morten
session_2.text: Yes, because you work so much. Mr. Rorlund says work is a punishment for our sins.

session_2.speaker: Ejlif
session_2.text: Pooh, what a duffer, you are, to believe a thing like that!

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Come, come, Ejlif!

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: That's capital!

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Don't you want to work as hard as that, Morten?

session_2.speaker: Morten
session_2.text: No, indeed I don't.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: What do you want to be, then?

session_2.speaker: Morten
session_2.text: I should like best to be a Viking,

session_2.speaker: Ejlif
session_2.text: You would have to be a pagan then.

session_2.speaker: Morten
session_2.text: Well, I could become a pagan, couldn't I?

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: I agree with you, Morten! My sentiments, exactly.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: I am sure that is not true, Mr. Billing.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Yes, I swear it is! I am a pagan, and I am proud of it. Believe me, before long we shall all be pagans.

session_2.speaker: Morten
session_2.text: And then shall be allowed to do anything we like?

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Well, you'll see, Morten.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: You must go to your room now, boys; I am sure you have some lessons to learn for tomorrow.

session_2.speaker: Ejlif
session_2.text: I should like so much to stay a little longer—

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: No, no; away you go, both of you,

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Do you really think it can do the boys any harm to hear such things?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: I don't know; but I don't like it.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: But you know, mother, I think you really are wrong about it.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Maybe, but I don't like it—not in our own home.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: There is so much falsehood both at home and at school. At home one must not speak, and at school we have to stand and tell lies to the children.

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: Tell lies?

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Yes, don't you suppose we have to teach them all sorts of things that we don't believe?

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: That is perfectly true.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: If only I had the means, I would start a school of my own; and it would be conducted on very different lines.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Oh, bother the means—!

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: Well if you are thinking of that, Miss Stockmann, I shall be delighted to provide you with a schoolroom. The great big old house my father left me is standing almost empty; there is an immense dining-room downstairs—

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Thank you very much; but I am afraid nothing will come of it.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: No, Miss Petra is much more likely to take to journalism, I expect. By the way, have you had time to do anything with that English story you promised to translate for us?

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: No, not yet, but you shall have it in good time.

session_2.speaker: STAGE
session_2.text: (DR. STOCKMANN comes in from his room with an open letter in his hand.)

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Well, now the town will have something new to talk about, I can tell you!

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Something new?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: What is this?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: A great discovery, Katherine.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Really?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: A discovery of yours?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: A discovery of mine. Just let them come saying, as usual, that it is all fancy and a crazy man's imagination! But they will be careful what they say this time, I can tell you!

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: But, father, tell us what it is.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, yes—only give me time, and you shall know all about it. If only I had Peter here now! It just shows how we men can go about forming our judgments, when in reality we are as blind as any moles—

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: What are you driving at, Doctor?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Isn't it the universal opinion that our town is a healthy spot?

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Certainly.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Quite an unusually healthy spot, in fact—a place that deserves to be recommended in the warmest possible manner either for invalids or for people who are well—

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, but my dear Thomas—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: And we have been recommending it and praising it—I have written and written, both in the "Messenger" and in pamphlets...

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Well, what then?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: And the Baths—we have called them the "main artery of the town's life-blood," the "nerve-centre of our town," and the devil knows what else—

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: "The town's pulsating heart" was the expression I once used on an important occasion.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Quite so. Well, do you know what they really are, these great, splendid, much praised Baths, that have cost so much money—do you know what they are?

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: No, what are they?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, what are they?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: The whole place is a pest-house!

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: The Baths, father?

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Our Baths?

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: But, Doctor—

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Absolutely incredible!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: The whole Bath establishment is a whited, poisoned sepulchre, I tell you—the gravest possible danger to the public health! All the nastiness up at Molledal, all that stinking filth, is infecting the water in the conduit-pipes leading to the reservoir; and the same cursed, filthy poison oozes out on the shore too—

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: Where the bathing-place is?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Just there.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: How do you come to be so certain of all this, Doctor?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: I have investigated the matter most conscientiously. For a long time past I have suspected something of the kind. Last year we had some very strange cases of illness among the visitors—typhoid cases, and cases of gastric fever—

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, that is quite true.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: At the time, we supposed the visitors had been infected before they came; but later on, in the winter, I began to have a different opinion; and so I set myself to examine the water, as well as I could.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Then that is what you have been so busy with?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Indeed I have been busy, Katherine. But here I had none of the necessary scientific apparatus; so I sent samples, both of the drinking-water and of the sea-water, up to the University, to have an accurate analysis made by a chemist.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: And have you got that?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Here it is! It proves the presence of decomposing organic matter in the water—it is full of infusoria. The water is absolutely dangerous to use, either internally or externally.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: What a mercy you discovered it in time.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: You may well say so.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: And what do you propose to do now, Doctor?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: To see the matter put right, naturally.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Can that be done?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: It must be done. Otherwise the Baths will be absolutely useless and wasted. But we need not anticipate that; I have a very clear idea what we shall have to do.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: But why have you kept this all so secret, dear?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Do you suppose I was going to run about the town gossiping about it, before I had absolute proof? No, thank you. I am not such a fool.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Still, you might have told us—

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Not a living soul. But tomorrow you may run around to the old Badger—

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: Oh, Thomas! Thomas!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Well, to your grandfather, then. The old boy will have something to be astonished at! I know he thinks I am cracked—and there are lots of other people who think so too, I have noticed. But now these good folks shall see—they shall just see! There will be a nice upset in the town, Katherine; you can't imagine what it will be. All the conduit-pipes will have to be relaid.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: All the conduit-pipes—?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Yes, of course. The intake is too low down; it will have to be lifted to a position much higher up.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Then you were right after all.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Ah, you remember, Petra—I wrote opposing the plans before the work was begun. But at that time no one would listen to me. Well, I am going to let them have it now.  Of course I have prepared a report for the Baths Committee; I have had it ready for a week, and was only waiting for this to come. Now it shall go off at once. Look at that! Four closely written sheets!—and the letter shall go with them. Give me a bit of paper, Katherine—something to wrap them up in. That will do! Now give it to-to-(stamps his foot)—what the deuce is her name?—give it to the maid, and tell her to take it at once to the Mayor.

session_2.speaker: STAGE
session_2.text: (Mrs. Stockmann takes the packet and goes out through the dining-room.)

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: What do you think Uncle Peter will say, father?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: What is there for him to say? I should think he would be very glad that such an important truth has been brought to light.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: Will you let me print a short note about your discovery in the Messenger?

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: I shall be very much obliged if you will.

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: It is very desirable that the public should be informed of it without delay.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Certainly.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: She has just gone with it.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Upon my soul, Doctor, you are going to be the foremost man in the town!

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Nonsense! As a matter offact I have done nothing more than my duty. I have only made a lucky find—that's all. Still, all the same...

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: Hovstad, don't you think the town ought to give Dr. Stockmann some sort of testimonial?

session_2.speaker: Hovstad
session_2.text: I will suggest it, anyway.

session_2.speaker: Billing
session_2.text: And I will speak to Aslaksen about it.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: No, my good friends, don't let us have any of that nonsense. I won't hear anything of the kind. And if the Baths Committee should think of voting me an increase of salary, I will not accept it. Do you hear, Katherine?—I won't accept it.

session_2.speaker: Mrs. Stockmann
session_2.text: You are quite right, Thomas.

session_2.speaker: Petra
session_2.text: Your health, father!

session_2.speaker: Hovstad and Billing
session_2.text: Your health, Doctor! Good health!

session_2.speaker: Horster
session_2.text: I hope it will bring you nothing but good luck.

session_2.speaker: Dr. Stockmann
session_2.text: Thank you, thank you, my dear fellows! I feel tremendously happy! It is a splendid thing for a man to be able to feel that he has done a service to his native town and to his fellow-citizens. Hurrah, Katherine!
